companyTypes.heading: Types of Companies under the Saudi Companies Law

items.name: General Partnership
items.desc: Founded by two or more individuals/entities who are jointly and personally liable for company debts and obligations. Partners acquire the status of “trader”.for more info.<contact>contact us</contact>.

items.name: Limited Partnership
items.desc: Includes at least one general partner personally liable for company debts and at least one limited partner liable only up to their share in capital, without acquiring trader status.for more info.<contact>contact us</contact>

items.name: Joint Stock Company (JSC)
items.desc: Founded by one or more persons; capital is divided into tradable shares. The company alone is liable for its debts; shareholders are liable only up to the value of subscribed shares.for more info.<contact>contact us</contact>

items.name: Simplified Joint Stock Company (SJSC)
items.desc: Founded by one or more persons; capital is divided into tradable shares. SJSC follows JSC rules unless otherwise stated.for more info.<contact>contact us</contact>

items.name: Limited Liability Company (LLC)
items.desc: Founded by one or more persons; it has a separate legal personality. The company alone is liable for its debts; owners/partners are liable only up to their share in the capital.for more info.<contact>contact us</contact>

items.title: How to Establish a Company in Bahrain for Foreigners
items.desc: Starting a company in Bahrain is not complicated, but it does require following a series of organized steps to ensure all legal requirements are met. Below are ten essential steps for foreigners looking to establish a business in Bahrain:
bullets: Obtain a Security Clearance — background check by NPRA for all involved individuals.
Register a Unique Company Name — submit and reserve on the relevant government portal to avoid duplication.
Choose and Approve Office Location — officials verify the site complies with activity/zoning rules.
Prepare Legal Documents — draft MOA/AOA and required shareholder/board resolutions with a legal advisor.
Open a Business Bank Account — provide MOA, trade license/CR (as applicable), IDs, and bank KYC documents.
Build the Right Team — hire local and/or foreign employees to match your business needs and scale.
Choose the Right Legal Structure — e.g., WLL/LLC, SPC, JSC, branch, or representative office.
Provide Proof of Business Address — submit a valid lease or approved virtual office documentation.
Register the Memorandum of Association — file with the Commercial Registry via Sijilat.
Processing Time — typically ~20–45 working days, depending on documents and approvals.

items.title: Requirements Based on Investor Type
items.desc: Key differences across resident, GCC, and non-GCC investors:
bullets: Residents in Bahrain: easy registration on Sijilat; no Bahraini partner required; some sectors (finance, education, healthcare, etc.) need special approvals; eligible for work/investor visas.

Citizens of GCC Countries: treated like Bahraini nationals in most sectors; can own 100% without a local partner; can purchase property under the company; no local sponsor needed; benefit from local incentives.

Foreign Investors (Non-GCC Residents): 100% foreign ownership allowed in many sectors (IT, consulting, logistics, e-commerce, restaurants, manufacturing…); some sectors need a Bahraini partner (e.g., General Trading 0.01% Bahraini; Construction & Contracting 51% Bahraini); can register via Sijilat or through service providers.

items.title: Government Incentives and Support
items.desc: Ownership, cost, and growth support programs:
bullets: Tax Exemptions: no personal or corporate income tax (except oil); VAT 10% on applicable supplies.
100% Foreign Ownership: widely allowed; local partner only in a few activities.
Government Support & Financing: Tamkeen offers interest-free/soft financing, local hiring support, and salary support (often 50–75% in early years).
Free Zones & Business Parks: e.g., Bahrain Logistics Zone (BLZ) and Bahrain International Investment Park (BIIP) with customs benefits, export support, and ready infrastructure.

items.title: Advantages of Establishing a Company in Bahrain for Foreigners
items.desc: Operational strengths that appeal to international founders:
bullets: Strategic Location: gateway to the Gulf with direct access to Saudi Arabia via King Fahd Causeway.
Low Setup Costs: company setup can start around BHD 1,000 (one thousand Bahraini dinars).
Strong Government Support: streamlined visas and regulatory processes for investors.
Excellent Infrastructure: international airport, major seaport, and efficient road networks.
Safe and Secure Environment: high safety and low crime, supporting business stability.

items.title: Challenges Foreigners May Face
items.desc: Plan ahead for these common hurdles:
bullets: Local Partnership Requirement in Some Sectors.
Bureaucratic Procedures may slow some steps due to formalities.
Extra Fees and Permits in certain activities (including annual charges).

items.title: Investor Visa in Bahrain
items.desc: Who qualifies and what you need:
bullets: Issued to owners of licensed and registered companies; validity usually 2 years or more; extendable to spouse and children.
Typical requirements: Commercial Registration copy, office lease agreement, capital certificate, medical check-up and fingerprinting, health insurance, and ID card.
